Authors: Michael Loizides, Matteo Carbone, Pablo Alvarado
Title:
Geoglossum dunense (Ascomycota, Geoglossales): a new sand
dune species from Cyprus
Keywords:
ITS, 28S LSU, phylogeny, Geoglossaceae, Geoglossomycetes,
earth tongue, Mediterranean
Abstract:
The genus Geoglossum Pers. is characterized by dark,
greyish-brown or black terrestrial ascocarps, typically consisting of a
fertile, club or tongue-shaped head and a sterile, indistinctly
delimited stipe. Because of their blunt and largely undifferentiated
macromorphology, their microscopic features, especially the spore shape,
size, colour and number of septa, together with the morphology of the
paraphyses, are critical in the discrimination of the species. Even
though it has been hypothesized that several species could be associated
with various plants and mosses (Nitare, 1982; Bergemann &
Garbelotto, 2006; Ohenoja et al., 2010; Wang et al., 2011), the ecology
of Geoglossum and related genera remains insufficiently understood and,
so far, no clear correlations between the various species and potential
hosts have been conclusively established (Hustad et al., 2013). A number
of taxonomic and monographic studies over the years have mainly focused
on American and Northern or Central European collections (Durand, 1908,
1921; Mains, 1940, 1954, 1955; Imai, 1940; Nannfeldt, 1942; Hakelier,
1967; Nitare, 1983, 1984, 1988; Læssøe & Elborne, 1984; Olsen, 1986;
Hallgrimsson, 1987; Schoch et al., 2009; Kučera & Gaisler, 2012;
Hustad et al., 2013). By contrast, the genus had been, until recently,
poorly documented in Southern Europe and the Mediterranean basin (Priou,
1992).
